nodes.label: Brandon Shorenstein
nodes.desc:
Shorenstein is the head of real estate company Shorenstein Realty Services.

Shorenstein’s father, Douglas Shorenstein, was chair of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. His grandfather, Walter Shorenstein, was a major Democratic donor and the city's biggest landlord.

In 2020, Shorenstein was a major donor to the political pressure group SF That Works For Everyone, launched by mayoral candidate Daniel Lurie in 2020.

His company has given at least $766,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Jean-Pierre Conte
nodes.desc:
Jean-Pierre Conte is the chair and managing partner of Genstar Capital, a San Francisco private equity firm that reportedly manages $49 billion of assets.

Conte is the founder of the Conte Initiative on Immigration Reform at the conservative Hoover Institute. He has also helped fund research into neuro-degenerative disorders and was one of the main funders of the Bay Lights project in 2015.

Conte has donated at least $503,808 in stock to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Louise Muhlfeld Patterson
nodes.desc:
Muhlfeld Patterson was vice president of HR at American Express for 14 years. She now serves as a trustee for multiple private schools, plus the SF Zoological Society.

She is a director of Neighbors For A Better SF Advocacy and is married to Arthur Patterson, a director of its associated 501(c)3, Neighbors For A Better SF.

She has donated at least $684,544 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: William Oberndorf
nodes.desc:
Oberndorf is a billionaire hedge-fund manager. He is a director of Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, and the president of its associated 501(c)3, Neighbors for a Better SF.

He is a top charter school advocate and has donated tens of millions to Republican senators, congressmen, and some moderate or right-leaning Democrats.

Oberndorf has donated at least $902,723 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, making him the group's single biggest donor.

nodes.label: Steven Merrill
nodes.desc:
Merrill was head of Californian venture capital firm Merco Ventures for almost two decades. He donates to green groups in Tahoe and helps manage the Merrill Family Foundation. He is a director of Neighbors For A Better SF Advocacy.

He has donated at least $535,001 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, and $9,000 to the school board recall.

nodes.label: John Pritzker
nodes.desc:
Pritzker is the founder of San Francisco private equity firm Geolo Capital. He sits on several boards, including Daniel Lurie's anti-poverty nonprofit Tipping Point.

Pritzker has donated at least $550,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Michael Moritz
nodes.desc:
Michael Moritz is a journalist-turned-venture-capitalist billionaire. At Sequoia Capital, he invested in tech giants like Google, LinkedIn, and PayPal. He has funded grants in the Bay and internationally via the Crankstart Foundation and has donated to many causes.

In 2021, he provided $10M to launch Here/Say Media, now the for-profit San Francisco Standard, via his nonprofit Civic Action Labs. He used $3M to launch the political advocacy and volunteering group TogetherSF.

Moritz has donated at least $300,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Chris Larsen
nodes.desc:
Larsen is an angel investor who has co-founded multiple tech companies, most notably the money transfer software Ripple. He is one of the world's wealthiest people and has given grants to all manner of local organizations, from San Francisco State University to the police department.

He was a major donor to moderate political groups like Progress SF and GrowSF. He broke with his fellow tech execs by supporting Chesa Boudin during the 2022 recall.

Larsen has donated at least $300,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Mimi Haas
nodes.desc:
Haas is a billionaire businesswoman and the widow of Peter E. Strauss, of the Levi Strauss fortune. She is the mother of Daniel Lurie, the mayoral candidate and founder of anti-poverty nonprofit Tipping Point.

Haas has donated at least $729,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy. She supported the school board and Chesa Boudin recalls in 2022.

nodes.label: William Fisher
nodes.desc:
Fisher is a billionaire investor and the director of clothing brand Gap Inc. He has is a firm advocate for charter schools, has donated heavily to Stanford, and gave over $1M to oppose a tax on income above $2M.

Fisher has donated at least $350,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Tom Chavez
nodes.desc:
Chavez is the founder of the San Francisco tech start-up incubator super{set}. He helps run the Chavez Family Foundation, which invests in immigration and education nonprofits, and he sits on the KQED board.

Chavez has donated at least $381,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

nodes.label: Kilroy Realty, L.P.
nodes.desc:
Run by John Kilroy, Kilroy Realty is an investment company based in San Francisco. He has characterized the city as an addict that has hit rock bottom, and has stated his opposition to progressive prosecutors, judges, and supervisors.

Kilroy's company has donated at least $242,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Christopher James
nodes.desc:
James founded the investment firm Engine No. 1 'based on his vision that capitalism can be harnessed for positive change'. He co-founded Daniel Lurie's anti-poverty nonprofit Tipping Point. He formerly operated a coal mine.

James has donated at least $200,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Jason Moment
nodes.desc:
Moment is a managing partner at the SF-based Route One Investment Company hedge fund, alongside fellow donor Bill Duhamel.

He is on multiple boards around the city, including the UCSF Foundation, the Benioff Children's Hospital, and the Fine Arts Museums of SF - where he took over from another fellow donor, Diane “Dede” Wilsey.

Moment has donated at least $200,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: John C. Atwater
nodes.desc:
Atwater is founder and CEO of Prime Group, a real estate investment company with over $15 billion in assets.

Atwater has donated at least $200,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, and some $49,999 to the Chesa Boudin recall.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: David deWilde
nodes.desc:
deWilde is an investor with a focus on real estate in San Francisco. We has worked on Wall Street and has taught at the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

He has donated at least $200,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Christopher Conway
nodes.desc:
Conway is a partner at the investment firm SV Angel. He founded the company with his father, Ron Conway, who is also a major donor to city political causes.

He has donated at least $189,480 in stock to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Bill Duhamel
nodes.desc:
Duhamel is the founding partner at the SF-based Route One Investment Company hedge fund, where he works alongside fellow donor Jason Moment. He has made large donations to Republicans and Democrats.

He has donated at least $160,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, as well as $40,000 to the Chesa Boudin recall.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Matthew Paige
nodes.desc:
Paige works in real estate with Twin Tree Venture, LLC. He has donated to both Republicans and Democrats, and gave $100,000 to the campaign against Prop. 30 in 2022, which would have increased income tax on millionaires to subsidize electric cars.

He has donated at least $159,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Paul Holden Spaht Jr.
nodes.desc:
Spaht is a managing partner at Thomas Bravo, a software investment firm. He is also president of the Spaht Family Foundation.

He has donated at least $150,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Robert Reniers
nodes.desc:
Reniers ran the Sun Pacific fruit company in San Joaquin Valley. In retirement, he has sat on several boards.

He has donated at least $150,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, while his wife Betsy Reniers has donated at least $50,000.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Boston Properties, Inc.
nodes.desc:
Boston Properties is a real estate investment company with assets around $24B. It is run by Mortimer Zuckerman, a billionaire media tycoon and investor who has donated to both Democrats and Republicans.

The company has donated at least $150,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Bruce Dunlevie
nodes.desc:
Dunlevie is a venture capitalist who focuses on tech startups. He is the managing partner of Benchmark Capital and has served on the Stanford University board of trustees. He is a major Republican donor.

He has donated at least $100,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Park Hotels & Resorts, Inc.
nodes.desc:
Park Hotels & Resorts is a real estate investment trust that focuses on hotels. It has around $9B in assets. The company relinquished two San Francisco hotels to lenders in June 2023, reportedly to reduce 'current exposure to the San Francisco market.'

The company has donated at least $100,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Tony Salewski
nodes.desc:
Salewski is a managing partner at Genstar Capital, a San Francisco-based private equity firm. He is major Democratic donor.

He has donated at least $100,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Arash Salkhi
nodes.desc:
Salkhi is the owner of Salkhi Petroleum Inc, a company that operates gas stations across California. He has donated to Republicans including Donald Trump.

He has donated at least $100,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Christopher Redlich
nodes.desc:
Redlich is the chairman of the nonprofit Healing Healthcare. He is on several boards, including at Stanford University and the Hoover Institute.

He has donated at least $100,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Kevin Marchetti
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Alexander Mehran
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: William Hume
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Ron Conway
nodes.desc:
Conway is a venture capitalist who has invested in many tech companies including Airbnb, Facebook, Google, and Reddit. He was a major backer for mayors Ed Lee and London Breed. He has donated to GrowSF, Progress SF, SF Guardians, and other causes on the national stage. Conway was previously on the board of tech advocacy org sf.citi.

He has donated at least $50,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Bernard Osher
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Arthur Rock
nodes.desc:
Rock was a venture capitalist and early investor in tech companies including Apple and Intel. The 96-year-old is now retired and is a major political donor, mainly funding moderate Democrats and pro-charter school candidates and propositions. He was the single largest donor to the school board recall, contributing roughly $500,000.

He has donated at least $50,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Diane Wilsey
nodes.desc:
Wilsey is a major Republican donor and San Francisco socialite. She is chair emerita of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

Wilsey has given $250,000 to Progress SF, $210,000 to open JFK Drive to cars, and $100,000 to the housing-focused Prop. D, among many other donations.

She has donated at least $50,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Mark Perry
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Building Owners And Managers Association
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Thomas Perkins
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Joseph Tobin
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Nancy Bechtle
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Jason M. Fish
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Daniel Lurie
nodes.desc:
Lurie is a philanthropist and the founder of the anti-poverty nonprofit Tipping Point. He also launched the short-lived SF That Works for Everyone nonprofit. In 2023, he announced his candidacy for San Francisco mayor.

He has donated at least $10,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy. Several of his associates – including Tipping Point co-founder Chris James, board member John Pritzker, and his mother Mimi Haas – have also donated to Neighbors.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Carole Mcneil
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: William Laney Thornton
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Diane Morris
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Joseph Wessinger
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Nick Podell
nodes.desc:
Nick Podell is a real estate developer and the president of Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.

Podell is best known in the Mission as the developer behind the so-called 'Beast on Bryant,' a market-rate project that included an offsite 100% affordable site after neighborhood protests.

He has donated at least $10,000 to Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.recipient_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy
nodes.desc:
Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy is a 501(c)4 nonprofit that funds moderate causes in San Francisco. Its money comes largely from extremely wealthy tech and real estate donors.

Since 2020, it has spent over $10M influencing elections and propositions. It raised the majority of the money for Chesa Boudin's recall and spent at least $468,800 on the school board recall.

nodes.label: Neighbors for a Better SF
nodes.desc:
Neighbors for a Better SF is a 501(c)3 nonprofit that describes itself as a 'committed to improving public safety, public education, and quality of life for our city.' It is not required to disclose its donors.

The 501(c)3 paid Brooke Jenkins, Boudin's opponent during the recall and now the District Attorney, $153,000 for purportedly unrelated consulting. It gave money to other nonprofits that in turn paid Jenkins, and donated to pro-recall groups.

Neighbors for a Better SF shares an address and several leaders with Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy, the main donor to the Chesa Boudin recall.

nodes.label: Chesa Boudin Recall
nodes.desc:
Boudin was San Francisco District Attorney from 2020 to 2022. He was elected on a platform of criminal justice reform but was ousted in a 2022 recall election for perceived softness on crime.

After being recalled, Mayor London Breed appointed his one time colleague and fierce critic Brooke Jenkins in July 2022.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy donated $4.7 million to the recall – over two-thirds of the total spent. Its associated 501(c)3 paid Jenkins a six-figure salary during the recall.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Workforce Housing Alliance PAC
nodes.desc:
The SF Workforce Housing Alliance PAC spent heavily in the 2020 supervisorial races. It spent $185,787 opposing Dean Preston, $120,756 opposing Connie Chan, and $42,414 supporting Joel Engardio, among other payments. It also contributed heavily to the pro-affirmative action Prop. 16.

Another group with an almost identical name opposed the mayoral bids of Mark Leno and Jane Kim in 2018.

The Workforce Housing Alliance PAC has received at least $843,000 from Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: School Board Recall
nodes.desc:
Gabriela López, Alison Collins, and Faauuga Moliga were all recalled from their positions on the school board by a wide margin in 2022.

Their opponents criticized them for not reopening schools fast enough during Covid-19, and Collins faced opposition over racially charged tweets. Much of the recall's funding came from very wealthy tech donors, including Garry Tan, David Sacks, and Zack Rosen.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy contributed at least $468,800 to the recall.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Opportunity For All Coalition
nodes.desc:
The Opportunity For All Coalition advocated for an amendment to the California state constitution that would allow affirmative action in work and education. The proposition ultimately failed.

The Opportunity For All Coalition received at least $446,000 from Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: No on Prop. I
nodes.desc:
The No on Prop. I campaign opposed an increase in transfer tax on large real estate deals. The proposition passed in 2020.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy contributed at least $239,500 to the No on Prop. I campaign.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Committee To Save Caltrain
nodes.desc:
The Committee To Save Caltrain supported additional funding for the state transit organization when ticket sales crashed during the pandemic. The campaign was successful and passed a small sales tax in 2020.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy contributed at least $196,000 to the Committee To Save Caltrain.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Edwin M. Lee Democratic Club
nodes.desc:
The Edwin M. Lee Democratic Club was formed in 1992. It seeks to represent Asian Pacific Islander Americans and typically leans moderate. Politicos Jay Cheng and Mary Jung are in its leadership.

The club has received at least $210,000 from Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Yes on Prop. 1 (2022)
nodes.desc:
Proposition 1 was a state constitutional amendment codifying the right to an abortion and contraceptives. It passed in 2022.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy contributed at least $180,000 to the Yes on Prop. 1 campaign.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: SF Common Sense Voter Guide
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: SF Health And Recovery Bond
nodes.desc:
The Health and Recovery Bond authorized the city to spend $487.5M on supportive housing, mental health, parks, and street safety. It passed in 2020.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy contributed at least $104,050 supporting the bond.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: No On Prop. 15
nodes.desc:
This 2020 state proposition would have required most commercial and industry properties to be taxed based on market value rather than purchase price. The proposition narrowly failed.

Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy contributed at least $100,000 opposing the proposition.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Campaign For Better SF Public Schools
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: No on Prop. C
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: No on Prop. H
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Yes on Prop. H
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: GrowSF
nodes.desc:
GrowSF is a political pressure group that aims to direct money and volunteers toward moderate candidates and policies in San Francisco. Much of its money comes from tech execs and investors such as Chris Larsen, Garry Tan, and Zachary Rosen.

GrowSF helped oust incumbent supervisor Gordon Mar in 2022. It was also an influential backer of the campaign to recall Chesa Boudin and supported the school board recall.

GrowSF has established PACs aiming to remove progressive supervisors Dean Preston and Connie Chan in the November 2024 election.

Grow SF has received at least $65,000 from Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Yes on Prop. G
nodes.desc:
Proposition G was a symbolic measure to urge the school district to teach algebra in eighth grade. The district had only offered it in ninth grade, except in special cases, an attempt to avoid separating students by ability early in their education. The measure passed in March 2024.
Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy donated at least $15,000 in support of the measure.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: No on Prop. B
nodes.desc:
Proposition B, put on March 2024 ballot by Supervisor Ahsha Safaí, would have tied San Francisco police staffing increases to identified future revenue. The measure did not pass.
Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy donated at least $826,040 against the measure.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Yes on Prop. E
nodes.desc:
Proposition E, put forward by Mayor London Breed, loosened police oversight and allowed for more surveillance and vehicle chases. It passed in March of 2024.
Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy donated at least $75,000 in support of the measure.
nodes.label_string: Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy

nodes.label: Committee to Fix San Francisco Government

nodes.label: Brooke Jenkins
nodes.desc:
Jenkins was the lead hate crimes prosecutor under Boudin until she resigned in 2021. She went on to volunteer on his recall campaign using materials from her time in the office.

Mary Jung connected Jenkins with three nonprofits when Jenkins began campaigning. She was subsequently paid by all three. Most notably, she received $153,000 from Neighbors for a Better San Francisco, a political group associated with the anti-Boudin recall, for purportedly unrelated consulting.

After the recall succeeded, Jenkins was appointed as the new District Attorney by Mayor London Breed. Jenkins secured her position in the November 2022 election.

nodes.label: Connected SF
nodes.desc:
Connected SF is a nonprofit run by Marie Hurabiell. Hurabiell is a tech co-founder and longtime Republican who joined the Democratic Party in 2022 after announcing her (unsuccessful) run for City College board.

The nonprofit was influential during 2022's contentious redistricting process, leading the drive to 'capture moderate majorities in Supervisor Districts which will ensure moderate centrist candidates are elected.'

Connected SF received a $450,000 grant from Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy in 2021, and a $85,000 grant in 2022.

nodes.label: Stop Crime Action
nodes.desc:
Stop Crime Action is a 501(c)4 nonprofit, and the political giving arm of Stop Crime SF. It advocates for more policing, more crime data transparency, and more aggressive enforcement against quality of life crimes.

Marie Hurabiell, the head of moderate group Connected SF, and supervisor Joel Engardio have both served on the Stop Crime SF board.

The group received a $650,000 grant from Neighbors for a Better SF Advocacy in 2021.

nodes.label: Stop Crime SF
nodes.desc:
Stop Crime SF is a 501(c)3 nonprofit. It has an associated PAC called Stop Crime Action. It advocates for more policing, more crime data transparency, and more aggressive enforcement against quality of life crimes.

Marie Hurabiell, the head of moderate group Connected SF, and supervisor Joel Engardio have both served on the Stop Crime SF board.

The group received a $100,000 grant from Neighbors for a Better SF in 2021.

nodes.label: Gotham By The Bay Media
nodes.desc:
Gotham By The Bay is the LLC behind substack newsletter Gotham. The newsletter is written by Susan Reynolds, ex-editor of the Marina Times. It has received at least $100,000 from Neighbors for a Better San Francisco and $59,000 from a GoFundMe launched by tech investor Jason Calacanis. The latter payment was made on the understanding that Reynolds would report critically on then-District Attorney Chesa Boudin.

Gotham focuses on crime, homelessness, and corruption in San Francisco. Gotham By The Bay LLC is incorporated in Wyoming at the same address as Mr Badly Productions.

nodes.label: Mr Badly Productions
nodes.desc:
Mr Badly Productions is a video production LLC focused on public safety and the police. It is run by Stanley Roberts, who was known for his 'People Behaving Badly' videos on KRON4 until he left in 2018.

Roberts now produces video for social media that often highlights crime and drug use in San Francisco. His LLC received $100,000 from Neighbors for a Better San Francisco in 2022.

nodes.label: Global SF
nodes.desc:
Global SF is a pro-business nonprofit. Its executive director, Darlene Chiu Bryant, is an associate of Mary Jung.

Neighbors for a Better San Francisco gave the nonprofit $20,000 in 2022. The same year, it paid Jenkins between $10,000 and $100,000. Jung connected Jenkins with the nonprofit while she was volunteering on the Boudin recall.

nodes.label: Sister's Circle Women Support Network
nodes.desc:
This nonprofit aims to support women who are unhoused, addicted to drugs, or coming out of incarceration.

Neighbors for a Better San Francisco gave the nonprofit $20,000 in 2022. The same year, it paid Brooke Jenkins between $10,000 and $100,000 while she volunteered for the Boudin recall.

Mary Jung, a member of the board, connected Jenkins with the group. The nonprofit is incorporated at 301 Grove Street, the same address as the San Francisco Association of Realtors, which is run by Mary Jung.
